summary: This document is a chain of emails from July 2020 between the FBI's NY CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team) and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) regarding the processing and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The emails discuss significant challenges in organizing, transferring, and reviewing terabytes of data from numerous devices, including issues with file formats, linking emails to attachments, and tracking which devices have been fully processed. This document is an email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York, likely to law enforcement or technical staff, discussing significant organizational challenges in processing electronic evidence from the Epstein case. The author describes receiving a hard drive with potentially hundreds of thousands of items but lacking a system to track which devices have been extracted, leading to confusion and risk of duplication.

persons.name: I. (NY) (FBI)
persons.role: FBI NY CART Coordinator, Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: Primary FBI point of contact coordinating the transfer and processing of digital evidence seized from Epstein's properties. They discuss technical challenges and timelines.

persons.name: M. (USANYS) (Contractor)
persons.role: Contractor for the U.S. Attorney's Office
persons.context: Involved in coordinating the receipt and processing of the digital evidence for the prosecution team, working with the FBI to get data into a usable format.

persons.name: M. (USANYS)
persons.role: Attorney or staff at the U.S. Attorney's Office
persons.context: Primary representative from the U.S. Attorney's Office requesting information, spreadsheets, and updates on the status of evidence processing and transfer.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The author of the email, expressing frustration and requesting a systematic approach to tracking electronic evidence from devices in the Epstein case.

connections.description: Working relationship between FBI forensic examiner and federal prosecutor to manage the transfer and review of seized digital evidence for the Epstein case.
Coordinating on technical details of data transfer, hard drive logistics, and processing methods for the evidence.
The U.S. Attorney's Office staff member is overseeing the contractor's work on processing the digital evidence for discovery.

events.title: Email coordination on evidence transfer
events.description: Email chain discussing plans for a call to resolve issues with how digital evidence from Epstein search warrants is organized and transferred.

events.title: Clarification on evidence format needs
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office clarifies they need raw data in a loadable format for Relativity to fulfill discovery obligations, not just for taint review.

events.title: FBI explains evidence processing challenges
events.description: FBI examiner details the massive scale of the digital evidence (terabytes from phones, tablets, servers, etc.), challenges with using Relativity, and delays due to methodological differences.

events.title: Major problems identified with received data
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office reports critical issues with over 1 million documents received: inability to link emails to attachments, mismatched control numbers, and files being invisible in their review system.

events.title: Request for comprehensive device accounting
events.description: Prosecution team requests a detailed spreadsheet to track all seized devices from Epstein's NY and USVI properties, what has been processed, and what remains.

events.title: Hard Drive Folder Modification
events.description: 38 folders labeled 'loadFiles' through '37loadFiles' on a hard drive were modified on this date, suggesting a prior data transfer or organization effort.

events.title: New Data Folder Creation
events.description: A folder titled 'NYCO24362' was modified on this date, containing over 600,000 items, which the author believes may be new materials not previously received.

keyFacts: The FBI seized a massive amount of digital evidence from Jeffrey Epstein's New York and US Virgin Islands properties, comprising terabytes of data from phones, tablets, servers, laptops, desktop computers, hard drives, CDs, and DVRs.

Significant technical and procedural challenges hampered the evidence review, including problems linking emails to attachments, mismatched file identifiers, and the prosecution's inability to use the data in their Relativity system for discovery.
The evidence included 9 IDE hard drives from Epstein's Manhattan apartment that were copies of drives from a July 2007 search of one of his properties.

The FBI and U.S. Attorney's Office had methodological disagreements, with the FBI preferring piece-by-piece review as devices were processed and the prosecution wanting a comprehensive transfer, which added to delays.
The emails reveal the investigation was still actively processing evidence and dealing with logistical issues in mid-2020, nearly a year after Epstein's arrest and death.
The prosecution team received a hard drive containing massive amounts of electronic evidence, with one folder alone holding over 600,000 items.
There is significant confusion and lack of organization in tracking which devices have been extracted and what data has already been received, risking duplication of effort.
The author requests a spreadsheet to systematically identify each device, its extraction status, and the contents of each data transfer to avoid 'a total disaster' in review.
The document highlights the scale and complexity of the digital evidence collection in the Epstein investigation.
